717880f-a.text:
(1)
5l4, 512, 510-508, 506, 504 Broome Street, north side, west of adjoining, and at West Broadway, at the triangular plaza
where Watts Street joins Broome.
February 12, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, not including Nos. 506 and 504. The loft building dates back around 1900. The frame-sided dormer windows, on the two remaining old houses -- the ones at the corner of Thompson Street were demolished aound 1923 -- would lead one to guess they are of frame construction; but they
are brick.
1932 or 1933.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 559.
717880f-a.folder: Broome Street & West Broadway, Manhattan, NY

(1)

724407f-a.text:
West Broadway, east side, north from Broome Street and showing loft structures partially hidden by the Sixth Ave. Elevated line.
May 7, 1938.
P. L. Sperr.
724407f-a.folder: West Broadway & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY

717877f-a.text:
504 and 506 Broome Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner
of West Broadway.
The loft structure partially seen at the left margin is
No. 508-10.
July 25, 1939
P. L. Sperr
717877f-a.folder: Broome Street & West Broadway, Manhattan, NY

717879f-a.text:
504-6 Broome Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of West Broadway, showing two old structures that have remained, reminiscent of earlier days. The Sixth Avenue "El," shown on West Broadway, will shortly
be demolished (1939).
October 9, 1939
Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project
717879f-a.folder: Broome Street & West Broadway., Manhattan, NY

724288f-a.text:
Watts and Broome Streets, intersection of West Broadway looking
westwards.
P. L. Sperr  July 25, 1939

724405f-a.text:
West Broadway, north from Broome (also Watts) Street's, showing this thoroughfare subsequent to the demolition of the old Sixth Avenue 'El7
July 25, 1939
P. L. Sperr
724405f-a.folder: West Broadway & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY

724406f-a.text:
West Broadway, south from a point just north of Broome Street, showing the Sixth Ave. Elevated line overshadowing this thoroughfare. Across the roofs of buildings shown, appears the outline of the New
York Telephone Building.
May 7, 1938.
P. L. Sperr.
The same locale, subsequent to 'El' demolition.
May 19, 1939
P. L. Sperr
N ~21(7.
724406f-a.folder: West Broadway & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY

724406f-b.folder: West Broadway & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY

724408f-c.text:
West Broadway, at,adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Broome Street. At the corner is a 3-1/2-story structure that bears No. 499 Broome Street. The 3-story addition is No. 361 West Broadway. A seven story loft structure forms an "L" with an address at No. 495 Broome Street. To the south of this are two low buildings (View 3); No. 357 West Broadway, being a former 2-1/2-story residence.
May 19, 1939
Views 1, 2, 3
P. L. Sperr
724408f-c.folder: West Broadway & Broome Street, Manhattan, NY
